title: Generative AI on Vertex AI - 設計文本提示
abstract:
# Generative AI on Vertex AI - 設計文本提示
本頁面簡要介紹了設計文本提示的一般指導。
如需在 Google Cloud 控制檯中直接遵循有關此任務的分步指導，請點擊 **操作演示** ：
[操作演示](https://console.cloud.google.com/?walkthrough_id=prompt_design&hl=zh-cn)
content:
## 支持的模型
- `text-bison`
- `text-bison-32k`
- `text-unicorn`
- `gemini-1.0-pro`## 提示結構
您可以向提示添加上下文信息、說明、示例、問題、列表和您能想到的任何其他類型的文本內容。通過向文本添加前綴來爲文本內容添加標籤。前綴可以是以冒號 (:) 結尾的字詞或短語，如以下示例所示。
- 文本：
- 問題：
- 答：
- 類別：
- 選項：
您可以使用您需要的任何前綴，但您可能會發現，對於給定任務，某些前綴的效果要優於其他前綴。您還應確保在提示中一致地引用前綴。
⛔ **不一致的引用：** 說明中使用了“情感”和“推文”，但前綴是“文本：”和“回答：”。
| 0                            |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the sentiment of the following tweet as positive or negative. Text: I love chocolate. Answer: |
✅ **一致的引用：** 前綴“文本：”和“情感：”與說明中使用的字詞一致。
| 0                            |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the sentiment of the following text as positive or negative. Text: I love chocolate. Sentiment: |
## 常見任務類型
您可以創建文本提示來處理任意數量的任務。一些最常見的任務包括分類、摘要和提取。您可以參閱以下頁面，詳細瞭解如何爲這些常見任務設計文本提示：
- [分類提示](#classification_prompts) 
- [摘要提示](#summarization_prompts) 
- [提取提示](#extraction_prompts) ## 分類提示
分類任務會爲文本分配類或類別。您可以指定可供選擇的類別列表，也可以讓模型從其自己的類別中進行選擇。本頁面介紹瞭如何創建對文本進行分類的提示。
### 分類用例
以下是文本分類的常見用例：
- **欺詐檢測** ：對金融數據中的交易是否欺詐進行分類。
- **垃圾郵件過濾** ：識別電子郵件是否爲垃圾郵件。
- **情感分析** ：將文本中傳達的情緒分類爲積極或消極。例如，您可以將電影評論或電子郵件分類爲正面或負面評價。
- **內容審覈** ：識別和標誌可能有害的內容，例如令人反感的語言或網上誘騙內容。
### 分類提示的最佳實踐
嘗試將溫度設爲零，將 Top-K 設置爲 1。由於分類任務通常具有確定性，因此這些設置通常可以產生最佳結果。
### 分類提示示例
使用以下示例瞭解如何爲各種用例設計分類提示。
- [情感分析提示](#sentiment-classification) 
- [內容分類提示](#content-classification) 
- [電影分類提示](#movie-classification) 情感分析會評估文本，並將其分類爲正面或負面。在分析評價、反饋和電子郵件等內容時，在提示中包含情感分析非常有用。
以下提示會對評價的情感進行分類：
| 0                                                                                         |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Give the sentiment of this review. Review: This is a shoe I will wear with black dress pants or jeans when I need comfort and a little style, but I am not impressed. This is a very flimsy shoe with little support at all. Unlike any other shoes I've purchased in the past. It looks nice, but it's not comfortable. 響應： Negative (gemini-1.0-pro) |
您可以指示模型解釋其推理過程，以使其返回回答背後的推理過程。
| 0                                                                                                                                                                                                |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Give the sentiment of this review and explain your reasoning. Review: This is a shoe I will wear with black dress pants or jeans when I need comfort and a little style, but I am not impressed. This is a very flimsy shoe with little support at all. Unlike any other shoes I've purchased in the past. It looks nice, but it's not comfortable. 響應： Negative The reviewer expresses disappointment with the shoe's lack of support and comfort, despite its stylish appearance. The reviewer also mentions that the shoe is flimsy and not like any other shoes they have purchased in the past. They say that the shoe looks nice, but it's not comfortable, which suggests that the style of the shoe is not enough to compensate for its lack of comfort. (gemini-1.0-pro) |
您還可以讓模型生成更結構化的響應，其中包含情感及其解釋該情感的原因。
| 0                                                                                                                                                                                      |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： For the given review, return a JSON object that has the fields sentiment and explanation. Acceptable values for sentiment are Positive or Negative. The explanation field contains text that explains the sentiment. Review: This is a shoe I will wear with black dress pants or jeans when I need comfort and a little style, but I am not impressed. This is a very flimsy shoe with little support at all. Unlike any other shoes I've purchased in the past. It looks nice, but it's not comfortable. 響應： ``` { "sentiment": "Negative", "explanation": "The reviewer is not impressed with the shoe, calling it flimsy and lacking support. They also say that it is not comfortable, despite looking nice." } ``` (gemini-1.0-pro) |
以下提示根據內容中的要求對客戶電子郵件進行分類。
| 0                                                                         |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the text as one of the following categories: - increase credit limit - cancel credit card - charge dispute Text: I lost my wallet yesterday so I need to cancel my credit card and get a new one. My card number is 1234. Category: 響應： cancel credit card (gemini-1.0-pro) |
如果電子郵件中的請求不明確，您可能需要將其發送給客戶服務團隊瞭解詳情。爲此，請添加“客戶服務”類別，並指示模型將此類別應用於需要更多信息的離羣值。
| 0                                                                                 |
|:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the text as one of the following categories: - increase credit limit - cancel credit card - charge dispute If the text doesn't fit any categories, classify it as the following: - customer service Text: I want to remodel my bathroom. What are my options? Category: 響應： Customer service (gemini-1.0-pro) |
處理需要更多信息的電子郵件的另一個選項是添加不適合任何其他類別的離羣值的示例。
| 0                                                                                                   |
|:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the text as one of the following categories: - increase credit limit - cancel credit card - charge dispute - customer service Text: I need to buy a car. Category: customer service Text: But I was in Chicago. Category: customer service Text: Where are my papers? Category: customer service Text: I want to remodel my bathroom. Category: 響應： customer service (gemini-1.0-pro) |
以下提示按照應該與誰觀看電影進行分類。
| 0                                                       |
|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Classify the following movie as one of the following categories: - watch alone - watch with friends - watch with family - watch on a date Text: The Goonies Category: 響應： Watch with friends (gemini-1.0-pro) |
您可能需要定義自己的類別。例如，假設您有一家名爲“Mimi Inn”的寵物酒店，該酒店放映寵物電影。電影選擇標準可能是：
- 主要角色必須是動物。
- 這部電影必須歡快。
- 影片不能是卡通片。
以下提示將符合三個條件的電影分類爲 ，並將所有其他條件歸類爲 。
| 0                                                                                                  |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Remi-tastic movies must meet the following criteria: - The main character must be an animal. - The movie must be family friendly. - The movie cannot be a cartoon. If a movie is not Remi-tastic, then it is Bark-fest. Classify the movie as one of the following categories: - Remi-tastic - Bark-fest Text: The Adventures of Milo and Otis Category: 響應： Remi-tastic (gemini-1.0-pro) |
如需檢查模型是使用標準還是隨機選擇分類，以下提示會包含有關返回分類原因的說明。
| 0                                                                                                                                                                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Remi-tastic movies must meet the following criteria: - The main character must be an animal. - The movie must be family friendly. - The movie cannot be a cartoon. If a movie is not Remi-tastic, then it is Bark-fest. Classify the movie as one of the following categories: - Remi-tastic - Bark-fest Explain why. Text: The Adventures of Milo and Otis Category: 響應： Remi-tastic Explanation: "The Adventures of Milo and Otis" is a live-action animal adventure movie featuring two main characters: Milo, a cat, and Otis, a pug. The movie is suitable for families of all ages and is not a cartoon. Therefore, it meets all three criteria for being Remi-tastic. (gemini-1.0-pro) |
## 摘要提示
摘要任務從文本中提取最重要的信息。可以在提示中提供信息來幫助模型創建摘要，也可以要求模型自行創建摘要。本頁面介紹如何設計提示以創建不同類型的摘要。
### 彙總應用場景
以下是彙總的常見應用場景：
- **總結文字** ：總結文字內容，例如：- 新聞報道。
- 研究論文。
- 法律文件。
- 財務文檔。
- 技術文檔。
- 客戶反饋。
- **內容生成** ：爲文章、博客或產品說明生成內容。
### 最佳實踐
請遵循以下準則來創建最佳文本摘要：
- 指定您所需的摘要具有的任何特徵。
- 如需更有創意的摘要，請指定更高的 temperature、top-K 和 top-P 值。如需瞭解詳情，請參閱 [文本參數定義](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/start/quickstarts/api-quickstart?hl=zh-cn#parameter_definitions) 中的`temperature`、`topK`和`topP`參數。
- 在編寫提示時，請專注於摘要的用途以及您要從中獲得什麼。
### 彙總提示示例
使用以下示例瞭解如何爲各種用例設計彙總提示。
- [文章彙總提示](#article-summarization) 
- [聊天彙總提示](#chat-summarization) 
- [# 標籤詞元化彙總提示](#hashtag-tokenization-summary) 以下提示總結了文章的要點：
| 0                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Provide a summary for the following article: The efficient-market hypothesis (EMH) is a hypothesis in financial economics that states that asset prices reflect all available information. A direct implication is that it is impossible to 'beat the market' consistently on a risk-adjusted basis since market prices should only react to new information. Because the EMH is formulated in terms of risk adjustment, it only makes testable predictions when coupled with a particular model of risk. As a result, research in financial economics since at least the 1990s has focused on market anomalies, that is, deviations from specific models of risk. The idea that financial market returns are difficult to predict goes back to Bachelier, Mandelbrot, and Samuelson, but is closely associated with Eugene Fama, in part due to his influential 1970 review of the theoretical and empirical research. The EMH provides the basic logic for modern risk-based theories of asset prices, and frameworks such as consumption-based asset pricing and intermediary asset pricing can be thought of as the combination of a model of risk with the EMH. Many decades of empirical research on return predictability has found mixed evidence. Research in the 1950s and 1960s often found a lack of predictability (e.g. Ball and Brown 1968; Fama, Fisher, Jensen, and Roll 1969), yet the 1980s-2000s saw an explosion of discovered return predictors (e.g. Rosenberg, Reid, and Lanstein 1985; Campbell and Shiller 1988; Jegadeesh and Titman 1993). Since the 2010s, studies have often found that return predictability has become more elusive, as predictability fails to work out-of-sample (Goyal and Welch 2008), or has been weakened by advances in trading technology and investor learning (Chordia, Subrahmanyam, and Tong 2014; McLean and Pontiff 2016; Martineau 2021). 響應： Summary: The efficient-market hypothesis (EMH) is a theory in financial economics that states that asset prices reflect all available information. This implies that it is impossible to consistently beat the market on a risk-adjusted basis. The EMH has been extensively researched, with mixed results. Some studies have found evidence of return predictability, while others have not. Recent research suggests that return predictability has become more elusive in recent years due to advances in trading technology and investor learning. The EMH provides the basis for modern risk-based theories of asset prices and frameworks such as consumption-based asset pricing and intermediary asset pricing. (gemini-1.0-pro) |
您還可以指定想要的摘要類型。例如，學術和科學期刊通常包含文章的摘要。以下提示要求模型撰寫文本的摘要：
| 0                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Write an abstract for this text: The efficient-market hypothesis (EMH) is a hypothesis in financial economics that states that asset prices reflect all available information. A direct implication is that it is impossible to 'beat the market' consistently on a risk-adjusted basis since market prices should only react to new information. Because the EMH is formulated in terms of risk adjustment, it only makes testable predictions when coupled with a particular model of risk. As a result, research in financial economics since at least the 1990s has focused on market anomalies, that is, deviations from specific models of risk. The idea that financial market returns are difficult to predict goes back to Bachelier, Mandelbrot, and Samuelson, but is closely associated with Eugene Fama, in part due to his influential 1970 review of the theoretical and empirical research. The EMH provides the basic logic for modern risk-based theories of asset prices, and frameworks such as consumption-based asset pricing and intermediary asset pricing can be thought of as the combination of a model of risk with the EMH. Many decades of empirical research on return predictability has found mixed evidence. Research in the 1950s and 1960s often found a lack of predictability (e.g. Ball and Brown 1968; Fama, Fisher, Jensen, and Roll 1969), yet the 1980s-2000s saw an explosion of discovered return predictors (e.g. Rosenberg, Reid, and Lanstein 1985; Campbell and Shiller 1988; Jegadeesh and Titman 1993). Since the 2010s, studies have often found that return predictability has become more elusive, as predictability fails to work out-of-sample (Goyal and Welch 2008), or has been weakened by advances in trading technology and investor learning (Chordia, Subrahmanyam, and Tong 2014; McLean and Pontiff 2016; Martineau 2021). 響應： The efficient-market hypothesis (EMH) posits that asset prices reflect all available information, making it challenging to consistently outperform the market on a risk-adjusted basis. This hypothesis has profoundly shaped modern risk-based theories of asset pricing, such as consumption-based and intermediary asset pricing. Empirical research on return predictability has yielded mixed results, with earlier studies often showing a lack of predictability while more recent ones have identified return predictors that later failed out-of-sample or were weakened by advances in trading technology and investor learning. This text delves into the theoretical underpinnings of the EMH, its implications for market anomalies and return predictability, and the ongoing debate surrounding the EMH's validity in the face of empirical evidence. (gemini-1.0-pro) |
用於爲文章創建標題的提示與使用短句來總結文章的提示類似。以下彙總提示會返回文章的標題。

The idea that financial market returns are difficult to predict goes back to Bachelier, Mandelbrot, and Samuelson, but is closely associated with Eugene Fama, in part due to his influential 1970 review of the theoretical and empirical research. Research in the 1950s and 1960s often found a lack of predictability (e.g. Ball and Brown 1968; Fama, Fisher, Jensen, and Roll 1969), yet the 1980s-2000s saw an explosion of discovered return predictors (e.g. Rosenberg, Reid, and Lanstein 1985; Campbell and Shiller 1988; Jegadeesh and Titman 1993). Since the 2010s, studies have often found that return predictability has become more elusive, as predictability fails to work out-of-sample (Goyal and Welch 2008), or has been weakened by advances in trading technology and investor learning (Chordia, Subrahmanyam, and Tong 2014; McLean and Pontiff 2016; Martineau 2021). 響應： 1. | 0                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Summarize the following conversation. Service Rep: How may I assist you today? Customer: I need to change the shipping address for an order. Service Rep: Ok, I can help you with that if the order has not been fulfilled from our warehouse yet. But if it has already shipped, then you will need to contact the shipping provider. Do you have the order ID? Customer: Yes, it's 88986367. Service Rep: One minute please while I pull up your order information. Customer: No problem Service Rep: Ok, it looks like your order was shipped from our warehouse 2 days ago. # 標籤詞元化是一種彙總形式，即模型從文本中提取代表整個文本的單詞和短語。
以下是使用 # 標籤詞元化的提示示例：
| 0                                                                                                                                   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Create some hashtags for this tweet: Google Cloud @googlecloud · Feb 25 We heard it through the grapevine: - Document AI Workbench is GA and ready for production use through APIs and the Google Cloud Console - Deliver higher model accuracy with Workbench - Build production-ready models faster with Workbench Read more ↓ 響應： - #DocumentAIWorkbench - #GA - #ProductionReady - #ModelAccuracy - #BuildFaster - #DocumentProcessing - #DataAnnotation - #MachineLearning - #AIPlatform - #GoogleCloud (gemini-1.0-pro) |
## 提取提示
提取提示可讓您從文本中提取特定信息。
### 使用場景
以下是提取的常見應用場景：
- **命名實體識別 (NER)** ：從文本中提取命名實體，包括人、地點、組織和日期。
- **關係提取** ：提取文本中實體之間的關係，例如人與人之間的家庭關係。
- **事件提取** ：從文本中提取事件，例如項目里程碑和產品發佈。
- **問答** ：從文本中提取信息以回答問題。
### 最佳實踐
嘗試將溫度設爲零，將 Top-K 設置爲 1。由於提取任務通常具有確定性，因此這些設置通常會產生最佳結果。如需瞭解詳情，請參閱 [文本參數定義](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/start/quickstarts/api-quickstart?hl=zh-cn#parameter_definitions) 中的 `temperature` 和 `topK` 參數。
### 提取任務示例
使用以下示例瞭解如何爲各種應用場景設計提取提示。
- [使用提取內容來回答問題](#answer-question-with-extraction) 。
- [設置提取內容的格式](#format-extracted-text) 。以下提示包括上下文和問題。模型在上下文中搜索問題的答案。
| 0                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Context: There is evidence that there have been significant changes in Amazon rainforest vegetation over the last 21,000 years through the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) and subsequent deglaciation. Analyses of sediment deposits from Amazon basin paleo lakes and from the Amazon Fan indicate that rainfall in the basin during the LGM was lower than for the present, and this was almost certainly associated with reduced moist tropical vegetation cover in the basin. There is debate, however, over how extensive this reduction was. Some scientists argue that the rainforest was reduced to small, isolated refugia separated by open forest and grassland; other scientists argue that the rainforest remained largely intact but extended less far to the north, south, and east than is seen today. This debate has proved difficult to resolve because the practical limitations of working in the rainforest mean that data sampling is biased away from the center of the Amazon basin, and both explanations are reasonably well supported by the available data. Q: What does LGM stands for? A: 響應： Last Glacial Maximum (gemini-1.0-pro) |
您可以從文本源中提取信息，並將其整理爲結構化格式。以下提示會將提取的文本轉換爲 JSON 文件：
| 0                                                                                                       |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 提示： Extract the technical specifications from the text below in a JSON format. Valid fields are name, network, ram, processor, storage, and color. Text: Google Pixel 7, 5G network, 8GB RAM, Tensor G2 processor, 128GB of storage, Lemongrass JSON: 響應： ``` { "name": "Google Pixel 7", "network": "5G", "ram": "8GB", "processor": "Tensor G2", "storage": "128GB", "color": "Lemongrass" } ``` (gemini-1.0-pro) |
## 後續步驟
- 瞭解如何 [發送 Gemini 聊天提示請求](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/multimodal/send-chat-prompts-gemini?hl=zh-cn) 。
- 使用 [Vertex AI Studio](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/start/quickstarts/quickstart?hl=zh-cn) 或 [Vertex AI API](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/start/quickstarts/api-quickstart?hl=zh-cn) 嘗試學習快速入門教程。
- 瞭解如何 [測試文本提示](https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/text/test-text-prompts?hl=zh-cn) 。
